tool_calls.result_content:
{"success":true,"issue":{"number":203,"title":"Create sloplib showcase repo based on Zulip discussion","state":"OPEN","labels":["ai-authored","idea:exploration"],"url":"https://github.com/e-vergo/SLS-Strange-Loop-Station/issues/203","body":"Use Playwright to read the sloplib thread on Leanprover Zulip and use it as a jumping off point to create a new showcase repository.

Thread: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113488-general/topic/sloplib/with/572015761

---
🤖 Created with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)","created_at":"2026-02-04T21:50:22Z"},"error":null}

{"stream":"general","topic":"sloplib","messages":[{"id":572004660,"sender":"Yakov Pechersky","content":"I am not yet ready to use AI to do global software package optimization. It too eagerly does local optima of one off scripts,, because that is effective and achieves the goal of the task at hand. And in general, we're not great at getting across an overarching vision and breaking it down into a coherent and consistent set of tasks.","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572005007,"sender":"Kevin Buzzard","content":"Here's another way of looking at it. There's that time at the end of a long (weeks or months) formalisation when you may no longer care about mathlib-standard code, you just put your head down and go for it. I'm just saying that maybe we could "put our heads down", get the remaining 1000 or so definitions needed in order to state all the big new theorems in all areas of mathematics (I suspect we need less than 1000 if Annals is anything to go by) and then say "yay AI let's go, Lean now understands every mathematical question that humans can ask, so now go prove some". Right now we're not going to get to this point for several years at least but I'm arguing that we could be there in several months with sloplib.","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572005215,"sender":"Yakov Pechersky","content":"I get it. You're saying, go as fast as possible to the top down approach. That will give a path and vision to what we actually need to factor out.","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572005972,"sender":"Rémy Degenne","content":"We are seeing AIs that can prove theorems about objects defined in Mathlib, where the definition comes with nicely designed API. I'm curious about how much of that capability remains if we are talking about a theorem that depends on several definitions that were AI generated in a sloppy way, with slop-API and whatever generality the AI used at that point.","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572006417,"sender":"Martin Dvořák","content":"I'd be happiest if the AI library was only adding new theorems about existing (Mathlib) definitions. Ideally if public definitions were forbidden. Then we also wouldn't have to worry about missing API.","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572006904,"sender":"Justin Asher","content":"It seems like the main point here is we need more research into how to effectively autoformalize definitions, because we have largely solved proving things in Lean using AI when given enough structure.","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572007065,"sender":"Martin Dvořák","content":"My personal opinion is that we shouldn't autoformalize definitions at all.","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572007379,"sender":"Bolton Bailey","content":"Kevin Buzzard said:

I'm just saying that maybe we could "put our heads down", get the remaining 1000 or so definitions needed in order to state all the big new theorems in all areas of mathematics (I suspect we need less than 1000 if Annals is anything to go by) and then say "yay AI let's go, Lean now understands every mathematical question that humans can ask, so now go prove some".

I think this idea makes a lot of sense. I have thought about something like this in these terms: The most starred repository on reservoir is mathlib, which is only for theorems we know are true and have sorry-free proofs of. We also have a repository in formal-conjectures which is the fifth-most starred on reservoir (I might put it as the second most-starred out of repos accepting generally any field of math) which is for conjectures we don't know are true, and therefore can only be sorrys. It feels like there should be a middle ground library for theorems we know are true, but don't have sorry free proofs of. Not least because these are the main theorems where today's AI could help us (proofs of various Eros problems notwithstanding).","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572010184,"sender":"Kevin Buzzard","content":"But that's exactly the repo I'm making with my RenPhil money -- formal statements of recent Annals papers. It's just not public yet because it's not big enough to be interesting. The main bottleneck is missing definitions.","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572012561,"sender":"Bolton Bailey","content":"Well, I guess I think that your RenPhil project sounds great and I think and hope it will be a big success!
I think the only difference between your description of this project and what I usually envision when I think about a project like this is that I am not really familiar with Annals or big academic math journals in general, so I think more along the lines of "statements of theorems in the 1000+ theorems list" than "statements in the annals".","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.795Z","reactions":[]},{"id

{"stream":"announce","topic":"Side-by-side blueprint - Experience prototype","messages":[{"id":572055679,"sender":"Eric Vergo","content":"Hey everyone!
I'm proud to present something I've been working on: Side-by-Side Blueprint, a pure Lean port of LeanBlueprint with an integrated deployment pipeline. 
This takes first steps toward some of the Lean FRO goals Leo mentioned at Lean Together 2026. It isn't intended to be a the premier tool and I mostly built it for myself (it's the best way for me to learn). I'm hoping that by putting it out there some people might try it out and it can help shape what the FRO eventually works on. Before getting into the details, here are the highlights:
Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.12.19 PM.png
Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.28.15 PM.png
Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.11.49 PM.png
Features

Side-by-side proof display: LaTeX theorem statements displayed next to Lean code, with toggle controlled dropdown proof bodies
Hacked Verso implementation for syntax highlighting, hover information, type annotations, etc.
Project dashboard:  Key theorems, blocked items, messages, and other attributes at a glance
Dependency graph: Status-colored nodes, click-through to theorems, cycle/disconnected detection
Integrated paper generation: Same pipeline produces blueprint, HTML paper, and PDF
Dark mode, 
One-click websites: CI action generates and deploys everything

Example repos:

Complete project with blueprint and paper [General Crystallographic Restriction]
Full-scale existing project, no paper and a few bugs [Prime number Theorem]
Minimal test repo, shows all features [SBS-Test]

Technical stack (for the curious):

General-purpose tagging system [LeanArchitect] (@[blueprint] attribute)
Extracts and "dresses" Lean with reusable assets during elaboration [Dress]
The LeanBlueprint port; builds blueprint, dependency graph, paper [Runway]
CI action for easy integration into the lean template repo [dress-blueprint-action] 

Caveat: It's entirely vibe coded and not ready for prime time, but it could be with some work. Looking for feedback on what features matter most and what rough edges need smoothing first.
Happy to answer questions!","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.770Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572055785,"sender":"Unknown","content":"discussion thread: #ecosystem infrastructure > Discussion thread - Side by Side blueprint","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.770Z","reactions":[]}],"message_count":2,"participants":["Unknown","Eric Vergo"],"first_message_date":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.770Z","last_message_date":"2026-02-05T15:53:21.770Z"}

Is it possible to instead have this as a vscode extension or in the lean infoview? The one most annoying thing for me is how long it takes to build the blueprint, only to realise you've missed a dependency...","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:29.384Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572183935,"sender":"Alex Kontorovich","content":"You can serve it locally, where it builds much faster. (That's what I typically do with PNT+ and RealAnalysisGame projects.)","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:29.384Z","reactions":[]},{"id":572184611,"sender":"Yaël Dillies","content":"Yes, but I couldn't easily do this until recently due to gitpod wiping out any local config when restarting a workspace. Now that I use the uni's big computer, it shouldn't be so much of an issue anymore","timestamp":"2026-02-05T15:53:29.384Z","reactions":[]}],"message_count":4,"participants":["Alex Kontorovich","Yaël Dillies","Eric Vergo"],"first_message_date":"2026-02-05T15:53:29.384Z","last_message_date":"2026-02-05T15:53:29.384Z"}

tool_calls.input_summary: {"subagent_type": "sbs-developer", "description": "Research feasibility of showcase options", "prompt": "## Research Task: Evaluate Feasibility of Two Showcase Options\n\nYou are researching feasibili...

input_full.prompt:
## Research Task: Evaluate Feasibility of Two Showcase Options

You are researching feasibility for a third SBS showcase repo. We want to impress Kevin Buzzard by scaffolding something in the direction of his interests (Langlands program, number theory). 

**Context from Zulip**: Kevin's bottleneck is missing definitions. He specifically mentioned "connected reductive group over a field" as a test case, and his broader goal is stating theorems from recent Annals papers. He's working on a RenPhil project to formalize Annals statements.

### Option A: "Langlands Ladder"
Scaffold the dependency tree from basic objects up to "automorphic form for a connected reductive group over a number field". Show what's missing between mathlib and cutting-edge number theory.

### Option D: "Reductive Groups"  
Scaffold connected reductive groups specifically, following the structure Brian Conrad outlined:
- Affine group scheme of finite type over a field
- Unipotent elements/subgroups
- Unipotent radical
- Definition of "reductive" (trivial unipotent radical over algebraic closure)

### Your Research Tasks

1. **Mathlib Inventory**: Search mathlib for what currently exists toward these goals:
   - Affine group schemes
   - Hopf algebras
   - Unipotent groups/elements
   - Algebraic groups over fields
   - Automorphic forms (likely nothing, but check)
   - Reductive groups (likely nothing, but check)
   
   Use loogle, leansearch, and local_search as appropriate.

2. **Reference Sources**: Identify good autoformalization references for each option:
   - For Option A: What sources describe the Langlands dependency structure?
   - For Option D: Brian Conrad's notes, Borel's book, SGA3, Stacks Project
   
   Which has cleaner, more autoformalizable source material?

3. **Scope Assessment**: 
   - How many "missing definition" nodes would each option have?
   - Which has a more natural tree structure (good for SBS visualization)?
   - Which is more self-contained vs requiring deep rabbit holes?

4. **Recommendation**: Based on executability (not mathematical importance), which option should we pursue? Consider:
   - Available reference material quality
   - Current mathlib foundation
   - Natural fit for SBS visualization features
   - Ability to show meaningful progress even if mostly sorry

**Output**: A structured comparison with your recommendation and reasoning.

tool_calls.result_content:
[{"type": "text", "text": "Mathlib has adele rings. Now I have enough information to compile my assessment.

---

## Feasibility Assessment: Reductive Groups vs. Langlands Ladder

### 1. Mathlib Inventory

| Component | Status | Notes |
|-----------|--------|-------|
| **Hopf Algebras** | Available | `HopfAlgebra R A` with antipode, bialgebra structure |
| **Schemes** | Available | Full scheme theory via locally ringed spaces, Spec-Γ adjunction |
| **Group Objects in Categories** | Available | `GrpObj` typeclass (mentioned by Kevin) |
| **Modular Forms** | Available | `ModularForm Γ k` for congruence subgroups of SL₂(ℝ) |
| **Adele Rings** | Available | `NumberField.AdeleRing R K` with topology, algebra structure |
| **Finite Adele Ring** | Available | `NumberField.FiniteAdeleRing` (from Kevin's FLT work) |
| **Lie Algebras** | Available | Good coverage, Oliver Nash working on Cartan subalgebras |
| **Algebraic Groups** | **Partial** | No dedicated `AlgebraicGroup` type; can use `GrpObj` over schemes |
| **Unipotent Groups** | **Missing** | No definition of unipotent elements/subgroups |
| **Unipotent Radical** | **Missing** | No `Ru(G)` definition |
| **Reductive Groups** | **Missing** | No definition at all |
| **Automorphic Forms (general)** | **Missing** | Only modular forms for GL₂, not general G |
| **Connected Reductive over Field** | **Missing** | Blocked by missing definitions above |

### 2. Reference Sources Analysis

#### Option D: Reductive Groups

**Primary Sources:**
- [Brian Conrad's "Reductive Groups Over Fields"](https://virtualmath1.stanford.edu/~conrad/249BW16Page/handouts/249B_2016.pdf) (249B lecture notes, Tony Feng scribe) - clean dependency structure
- [J.S. Milne's "Reductive Groups"](https://www.jmilne.org/math/CourseNotes/RG.pdf) - 26 chapters with clear progression
- [Brian Conrad's "Reductive Group Schemes"](http://math.stanford.edu/~conrad/papers/luminysga3.pdf) - relative theory
- [Borel's "Linear Algebraic Groups"](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/linear-algebraic-groups/DDDFFCDA71D8B79698F4E77E66FD3B06) - standard reference

**Structure Quality:**
- Milne's notes have **25 sections with clear dependency chain**:
  1. Schemes → Algebraic groups → Examples → Group theory → Representations
  2. Lie algebras → Multiplicative groups → Unipotent groups → Solvable groups
  3. Borel/Cartan → Isogenies → **Semisimple/Reductive** → Root systems
- Brian Conrad provided explicit definition to Kevin:
  - "G is k-smooth and the unipotent radical of G_{kbar} is trivial"
  - Alternative: "G_{kbar} has no nontrivial smooth connected unipotent normal closed k-subgroup"

**Autoformalizable?** **YES** - the definitions are clean and well-structured. The dependency chain is:
```
Affine scheme → Group scheme of finite type → Smooth group scheme
                                                    ↓
Unipotent element → Unipotent subgroup → Unipotent radical → Reductive
```

#### Option A: Langlands Ladder

**Primary Sources:**
- [Knapp's "Prerequisites for the Langlands Program"](https://www.math.stonybrook.edu/~aknapp/pdf-files/china1.pdf)
- [Bump's "Automorphic Forms and Representations"](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/automorphic-forms-and-representations/F46424A2D9646FE32D9B792BC5E0238A)
- [Getz's "Introduction to Automorphic Representations"](https://sites.math.duke.edu/~jgetz/aut_reps.pdf)

**Structure Quality:**
- From Kevin's Zulip: "To define automorphic forms for connected reductive groups, two key missing pieces:
  1. Definition of reductive group (NB this is not a group, it's a group variety)
  2. Real points of smooth variety over ℝ are a real manifold"
- Knapp's paper notes: "To merely state the Langlands conjectures correctly requires much of the machinery of class field theory, the structure theory of algebraic groups, the representation theory of real and p-adic groups, and (at least) the language of algebraic geometry."

**Autoformalizable?** **DIFFICULT** - the definitions require:
- Reductive groups (Option D is a prerequisite!)
- Adelic groups G(A_K) with topology
- Smooth manifold structure on real points
- Representation theory of p-adic groups
- L-groups and Satake parameters

### 3. Scope Assessment

#### Option D: Reductive Groups

**Estimated node count:** 40-60 nodes

**Core dependency tree:**
```
1. Affine group scheme of finite type over k (5-8 nodes)
   - Affine scheme
   - Scheme of finite type
   - Group object structure
   - Morphism properties

2. Smooth group schemes (3-5 nodes)
   - Smoothness definition
   - Cartier's theorem (char 0)
   - Perfect field case

3. Unipotent theory (10-15 nodes)
   - Unipotent element (matrix definition)
   - Unipotent subgroup
   - Composition series with G_a quotients
   - Unipotent radical R_u(G)\

input_full.observation: Issue handoff friction: When issues are created from conversation context, future sessions lack the reasoning trail. Solution: Include explicit archive/conversation references in issue bodies (e.g., "Created from session X, archive entry Y") so receiving agents can query the archive and read the full deliberation context. The phrase "aligned on in a previous chat" is helpful but could be machine-actionable with entry IDs.

tool_calls.input_summary: {"title": "Create \"Reductive Groups\" showcase repo scaffolding path to connected reductive groups over a field", "body": "## Context: Kevin Buzzard's Sloplib Discussion\n\nThis issue emerged from th...

input_full.title: Create "Reductive Groups" showcase repo scaffolding path to connected reductive groups over a field
input_full.body:
## Context: Kevin Buzzard's Sloplib Discussion

This issue emerged from the Zulip thread [#general > sloplib](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113488-general/topic/sloplib) where Kevin Buzzard posed the question: could AI-generated "sloplib" accelerate progress toward stating hard theorems that mathlib can't yet express?

**Kevin's core bottleneck**: Missing definitions. He estimates ~1000 definitions needed to state all big new theorems. His specific test case: "connected reductive group over a field" — which he tried to formalize with Andrew Yang and got stuck immediately due to design decisions.

**Kevin's RenPhil project**: Formalizing statements of recent Annals papers. The bottleneck is not proofs but definitions.

**Brian Conrad's guidance to Kevin** (quoted in thread): The right definition is "G is k-smooth and the unipotent radical of G_{kbar} is trivial" — or shortcut: "G_{kbar} has no nontrivial smooth connected unipotent normal closed k-subgroup."

## Why This Showcase

The user announced SBS in [#announce > Side-by-side blueprint](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113486-announce/topic/Side-by-side.20blueprint.20-.20Experience.20prototype) and wants to demonstrate SBS's value to Kevin specifically. Kevin is a pillar of the Lean community and (justifiably) hard to impress.

**The pitch**: SBS as a tool for visualizing definition dependencies — showing exactly what's missing between mathlib and cutting-edge number theory. Even with mostly `sorry` nodes, the dependency graph makes the problem legible.

## Scope: 40-60 Nodes

### Dependency Tree Structure

```
1. Affine Group Scheme of Finite Type over k (5-8 nodes)
   ├── Affine scheme (mathlib: ✅)
   ├── Scheme of finite type (mathlib: ✅)
   ├── Group object structure via GrpObj (mathlib: ✅)
   └── Morphism properties

2. Smooth Group Schemes (3-5 nodes)
   ├── Smoothness definition
   ├── Cartier's theorem (char 0 case)
   └── Perfect field case

3. Unipotent Theory (10-15 nodes)
   ├── Unipotent element (matrix definition)
   ├── Unipotent subgroup
   ├── Composition series with G_a quotients
   ├── Unipotent radical R_u(G)
   └── Base change to algebraic closure

4. Reductive Definition (5-8 nodes)
   ├── Definition: R_u(G_{k̄}) = 1
   ├── Alternative characterizations
   └── Examples (GL_n, SL_n, SO_n, Sp_n)

5. Basic Structure Theory (15-20 nodes)
   ├── Tori and multiplicative groups
   ├── Borel subgroups
   ├── Root systems (connect to existing mathlib)
   └── Split vs non-split
```

### Mathlib Foundation (Already Available)

| Component | Status |
|-----------|--------|
| Hopf Algebras | ✅ `HopfAlgebra R A` |
| Schemes + GrpObj | ✅ Full scheme theory |
| Lie Algebras | ✅ Good coverage |
| Root Systems | ✅ Basic structure |

### Key Missing Pieces (This Showcase Fills)

- `IsUnipotent` for elements/subgroups
- `unipotentRadical` definition
- `IsReductive` definition
- Connection between Hopf algebra and scheme approaches

## Reference Sources for Autoformalization

1. **Brian Conrad's "Reductive Groups Over Fields"** (249B lecture notes, Tony Feng scribe)
   - https://virtualmath1.stanford.edu/~conrad/249BW16Page/handouts/249B_2016.pdf
   
2. **J.S. Milne's "Reductive Groups"** (26 chapters, clean progression)
   - https://www.jmilne.org/math/CourseNotes/RG.pdf
   
3. **Stacks Project Section 39.8** (Algebraic Group Schemes)
   - https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/0BF6

4. **Kevin's code snippet** (starting point):
```lean
import Mathlib

open CategoryTheory AlgebraicGeometry

-- let G be an affine group scheme of finite type over ℚ
variable (G : Scheme) (φ : G ⟶ Spec ⟨CommRingCat.of ℚ⟩)
  [GrpObj (Over.mk φ)] [IsAffine G] [LocallyOfFiniteType φ]
```

## Design Decision: Hopf Algebra vs Scheme

Kevin noted both approaches are valid for affine groups over a field. The Hopf algebra approach may be simpler for initial scaffolding. Brian Conrad mentioned the scheme approach is more general. We should scaffold both paths and show how they connect.

## Success Criteria

1. **Dependency graph** clearly shows path from mathlib foundations to `IsReductive`
2. **Dashboard** shows progress: what's proven, what's sorry, what's blocked
3. **Side-by-side display** shows Lean definitions alongside LaTeX from Milne/Conrad
4. **Examples** (GL_n, SL_n) demonstrate the definitions are usable
5. **Paper generation** produces readable exposition of the formalization

## Session Context

This issue was created from a conversation where the user and I:
1. Read the sloplib Zulip thread to understand Kevin's interests and bottlenecks
2. Evaluated two options (Langlands Ladder vs Reductive Groups)
3. Researched mathlib foundations and reference material quality
4. Aligned on Reductive Groups as the more executable option

**Archive note**: This is what the user and I aligned on in a previous chat. Future sessions working on this issue should consider querying the archive for entries around this issue's creation time to recover the full deliberation context (why we chose Option D over Option A, the detailed mathlib inventory, etc.).

## Related

- Kevin's RenPhil project (formalizing Annals statements)
- Kim Morrison's [merely-true](https://github.com/merely-true/merely-true) repo
- Kevin's gist attempt: https://gist.github.com/kbuzzard/dc7f3f41af331b8c9ba0bdf063934a6d

Future sessions working on this issue should consider querying the archive for entries around this issue's creation time to recover the full deliberation context (why we chose Option D over Option A, the detailed mathlib inventory, etc.).

## Related

- Kevin's RenPhil project (formalizing Annals statements)
- Kim Morrison's [merely-true](https://github.com/merely-true/merely-true) repo

input_full.title: Create "Reductive Groups" showcase repo scaffolding path to connected reductive groups over a field
input_full.body:
## Context: Kevin Buzzard's Sloplib Discussion

This issue emerged from the Zulip thread [#general > sloplib](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113488-general/topic/sloplib) where Kevin Buzzard posed the question: could AI-generated "sloplib" accelerate progress toward stating hard theorems that mathlib can't yet express?

**Kevin's core bottleneck**: Missing definitions. He estimates ~1000 definitions needed to state all big new theorems. His specific test case: "connected reductive group over a field" — which he tried to formalize with Andrew Yang and got stuck immediately due to design decisions.

**Kevin's RenPhil project**: Formalizing statements of recent Annals papers. The bottleneck is not proofs but definitions.

**Brian Conrad's guidance to Kevin** (quoted in thread): The right definition is "G is k-smooth and the unipotent radical of G_{kbar} is trivial" — or shortcut: "G_{kbar} has no nontrivial smooth connected unipotent normal closed k-subgroup."

## Why This Showcase

The user announced SBS in [#announce > Side-by-side blueprint](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/113486-announce/topic/Side-by-side.20blueprint.20-.20Experience.20prototype) and wants to demonstrate SBS's value to Kevin specifically. Kevin is a pillar of the Lean community and (justifiably) hard to impress.

**The pitch**: SBS as a tool for visualizing definition dependencies — showing exactly what's missing between mathlib and cutting-edge number theory. Even with mostly `sorry` nodes, the dependency graph makes the problem legible.

## Scope: 40-60 Nodes

### Dependency Tree Structure

```
1. Affine Group Scheme of Finite Type over k (5-8 nodes)
   ├── Affine scheme (mathlib: ✅)
   ├── Scheme of finite type (mathlib: ✅)
   ├── Group object structure via GrpObj (mathlib: ✅)
   └── Morphism properties

2. Smooth Group Schemes (3-5 nodes)
   ├── Smoothness definition
   ├── Cartier's theorem (char 0 case)
   └── Perfect field case

3. Unipotent Theory (10-15 nodes)
   ├── Unipotent element (matrix definition)
   ├── Unipotent subgroup
   ├── Composition series with G_a quotients
   ├── Unipotent radical R_u(G)
   └── Base change to algebraic closure

4. Reductive Definition (5-8 nodes)
   ├── Definition: R_u(G_{k̄}) = 1
   ├── Alternative characterizations
   └── Examples (GL_n, SL_n, SO_n, Sp_n)

5. Basic Structure Theory (15-20 nodes)
   ├── Tori and multiplicative groups
   ├── Borel subgroups
   ├── Root systems (connect to existing mathlib)
   └── Split vs non-split
```

### Mathlib Foundation (Already Available)

| Component | Status |
|-----------|--------|
| Hopf Algebras | ✅ `HopfAlgebra R A` |
| Schemes + GrpObj | ✅ Full scheme theory |
| Lie Algebras | ✅ Good coverage |
| Root Systems | ✅ Basic structure |

### Key Missing Pieces (This Showcase Fills)

- `IsUnipotent` for elements/subgroups
- `unipotentRadical` definition
- `IsReductive` definition
- Connection between Hopf algebra and scheme approaches

## Reference Sources for Autoformalization

1. **Brian Conrad's "Reductive Groups Over Fields"** (249B lecture notes, Tony Feng scribe)
   - https://virtualmath1.stanford.edu/~conrad/249BW16Page/handouts/249B_2016.pdf
   
2. **J.S. Milne's "Reductive Groups"** (26 chapters, clean progression)
   - https://www.jmilne.org/math/CourseNotes/RG.pdf
   
3. **Stacks Project Section 39.8** (Algebraic Group Schemes)
   - https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/0BF6

4. **Kevin's code snippet** (starting point):
```lean
import Mathlib

open CategoryTheory AlgebraicGeometry

-- let G be an affine group scheme of finite type over ℚ
variable (G : Scheme) (φ : G ⟶ Spec ⟨CommRingCat.of ℚ⟩)
  [GrpObj (Over.mk φ)] [IsAffine G] [LocallyOfFiniteType φ]
```

## Design Decision: Hopf Algebra vs Scheme

Kevin noted both approaches are valid for affine groups over a field. The Hopf algebra approach may be simpler for initial scaffolding. Brian Conrad mentioned the scheme approach is more general. We should scaffold both paths and show how they connect.

## Success Criteria

1. **Dependency graph** clearly shows path from mathlib foundations to `IsReductive`
2. **Dashboard** shows progress: what's proven, what's sorry, what's blocked
3. **Side-by-side display** shows Lean definitions alongside LaTeX from Milne/Conrad
4. **Examples** (GL_n, SL_n) demonstrate the definitions are usable
5. **Paper generation** produces readable exposition of the formalization

## Session Context

This issue was created from a conversation where the user and I:
1. Read the sloplib Zulip thread to understand Kevin's interests and bottlenecks
2. Evaluated two options (Langlands Ladder vs Reductive Groups)
3. Researched mathlib foundations and reference material quality
4. Aligned on Reductive Groups as the more executable option

**Archive note**: This is what the user and I aligned on in a previous chat. Future sessions working on this issue should consider querying the archive for entries around this issue's creation time to recover the full deliberation context (why we chose Option D over Option A, the detailed mathlib inventory, etc.).

## Related

- Kevin's RenPhil project (formalizing Annals statements)
- Kim Morrison's [merely-true](https://github.com/merely-true/merely-true) repo
- Kevin's gist attempt: https://gist.github.com/kbuzzard/dc7f3f41af331b8c9ba0bdf063934a6d

thinking_blocks.content: The user wants to see GitHub issue #203. I can use the sbs_issue_get MCP tool to fetch this.
Got the issue details. Let me present this to the user.

The user wants me to:
1. Read the sloplib Zulip thread to understand the context
2. Read their announcement thread to see the response (including Kevin Buzzard's)
3. Discuss options for a third showcase repo that could impress Kevin Buzzard

Kevin Buzzard is indeed a major figure in the Lean/formalization community - he's behind the Liquid Tensor Experiment, Formalizing Mathematics course at Imperial, and many influential mathlib contributions. He's known for being demanding but fair, and his interest would be a huge endorsement.

Let me fetch both Zulip threads to understand the context.
Excellent - I now have context on both threads. Let me also fetch the discussion thread that's referenced to see if Kevin Buzzard or others have commented there.

Okay, so I have a lot of context now. The announcement got some nice responses (Yaël Dillies asking about VS Code integration, Alex Kontorovich chiming in about local builds).

The sloplib thread is fascinating and reveals a lot about Kevin Buzzard's thinking:

1. **Kevin's RenPhil project**: He's working on formal statements of recent Annals papers. The bottleneck is missing definitions.

2. **The "sloplib" concept**: A fork of mathlib where AI-generated code is accepted with lower standards - proofs 10x as long, poorly maintained, but sorry-free. The question is whether this could accelerate progress toward stating and proving things that mathlib can't yet express.

3. **Kevin's specific challenge**: He wants to formalize "connected reductive group over a field" and automorphic forms. This is extremely complex - he shared Brian Conrad's detailed response about the definition difficulties.

4. **Kim Morrison's suggestion**: Kevin should write prompts at three levels (minimal, with references, detailed explanation) and Kim will test them with various AI tools (Aristotle, Claude, Codex).

5. **Key insight**: Kevin says "I don't know how I would like it done" - the design decisions are genuinely hard. Should it be a Hopf algebra or a scheme? What's the right definition of "reductive"?

Now, for a third showcase repo that could impress Kevin Buzzard:

**What Kevin cares about (from the threads):**
1. Acceleration toward stating big theorems (especially Langlands program)
2. Missing definitions being the bottleneck
3. The question of whether AI can help with hard design decisions
4. Formalizing statements from recent Annals papers

**What SBS offers that could be relevant:**
1. Visual dependency graphs - catch logical errors
2. Side-by-side display - see Lean alongside mathematical statements
3. Dashboard - track progress on complex formalizations
4. Blueprint structure - organize dependencies


5. A few concrete directions emerge: I could build a "Formal Statements" showcase that maps out the dependency structure needed for Annals theorems without proving them, just visualizing what definitions are missing. Or create a "Sloplib Experiment" scaffold that uses SBS to manage AI-generated proofs, tracking completion status and flagging definitions needing human review. A third option is scaffolding the "Connected Reductive Groups" structure Kevin outlined, with the affine group scheme and unipotent radical as starting points.

I could also pick recent Annals papers and create blueprints for stating their main theorems, or frame SBS as a tool for exploring alternative definition approaches—Kevin mentioned trying multiple strategies for schemes and group cohomology, and the dependency graph could help visualize those design choices. The key insight is that while I can't complete Kevin's full vision, I can build something that demonstrates SBS capabilities while moving in a direction he cares about, especially given how missing definitions are the real bottleneck and how AI-generated proofs need human review for correctness.

The most persuasive approach would connect to Kevin's actual work in Langlands and number theory, use SBS to organize complex definitional dependencies, show how visual tools enable "sloplib-style" exploration, and strike a balance between ambition and feasibility. I should present these options to him.

The user wants me to spawn an agent to research the feasibility of both options A (Langlands Ladder) and D (Reductive Groups). The agent should:
1. Evaluate current mathlib tooling for both directions
2. Identify good reference sources for autoformalization
3. Determine which is more executable given our capabilities

This is a research task that needs deep exploration of mathlib, understanding of the mathematical content, and identification of reference materials. I should spawn an sbs-developer agent (or actually, this is more of a research task - maybe an Explore agent would be better, but sbs-developer has the full context of our tooling and can do the research properly).

Actually, looking at the agent types available:
- Explore: Fast agent for exploring codebases, searching code for keywords
- sbs-developer: Development agent for Side-by-Side Blueprint toolchain

Since this is about evaluating feasibility from a mathematical/reference perspective and checking mathlib, I think I should use sbs-developer since it has "deep architectural knowledge" and can do comprehensive research. The task involves:
1. Searching mathlib for existing definitions
2. Looking at reference materials (stacks project, Brian Conrad's notes, etc.)
3. Evaluating what we'd need to build

Let me spawn an sbs-developer agent with a clear research mandate.

This is an excellent comprehensive analysis. The agent has:

1. Done a thorough mathlib inventory - found Hopf algebras, schemes, modular forms, adele rings exist; unipotent groups, reductive groups, and general automorphic forms are missing

2. Analyzed reference sources for both options - Brian Conrad's notes and Milne's course notes for reductive groups are clean and autoformalizable; Langlands material is more scattered

3. Estimated scope - Option D is ~40-60 nodes with a clean tree structure; Option A is 100-200+ nodes with complex parallel dependencies

4. Made a clear recommendation: **Option D (Reductive Groups)** because:
   - It's a prerequisite for Option A anyway
   - Better reference materials
   - Stronger mathlib foundation
   - Natural fit for SBS visualization
   - Directly addresses Kevin's explicit bottleneck

This is exactly the kind of analysis the user asked for. Let me summarize this for the user.

The user wants me to:

1. Log a new issue for the third showcase repo (Reductive Groups) with extensive context about Kevin Buzzard, the Zulip thread, etc.

2. Include a note like "this is what the user and I aligned on in a previous chat" to help future sessions understand the context

3. Capture an improvement observation about making issue handoffs smoother - the user is suggesting we could include references to the conversation/archive entry so future LLMs can look up the relevant context

Let me first capture the improvement observation, then create the issue with rich context.
Good, the improvement was captured. Now let me create the issue with rich context about Kevin Buzzard, the Zulip discussion, and all the relevant details for executing this showcase repo.
The label wasn't found. Let me try with different labels that exist in the taxonomy.
The labels aren't being found. Let me check what labels are available or just use simpler ones.

The issue was created successfully. Now let me also update this issue 203 to close it since it was superseded by 223 which is more detailed.

Actually, looking at it again - issue 203 was about creating a sloplib showcase repo based on Zulip discussion. Issue 223 is the concrete result of that exploration. I should probably link them together rather than close 203 - or I could close 203 with a reference to 223.

Let me close 203 with a comment pointing to 223.

Both tasks complete:
1. Captured the improvement observation about issue handoff friction
2. Created issue #223 with full context about the Reductive Groups showcase
3. Closed issue #203 with a reference to the new issue

Now let me summarize for the user.
The user wants to close out the chat. I should do a clean wrap-up. No need for TodoWrite here since we're finishing up, not starting new work.
